etymology.description: Ideogram: a point/dot; also depicted a small fire on a torch when used as the original form of 主.
etymology.interpretation: At its core, it is the simple indicative mark of a dot, corresponding to the brush stroke 点. In early graphs it could also picture a small flame perched on a torch, a role that fed into the ancient form of 主.

examples.chinese: 汉字里有一笔叫“点”(漢字裡有一筆叫「點」)，写作“丶”(寫作「丶」)。
examples.pinyin: Hànzì lǐ yǒu yī bǐ jiào “diǎn”, xiězuò “zhǔ”.
examples.english: In Chinese characters, there is a stroke called “dot,” written as “丶.”

examples.chinese: 写汉字时(寫漢字時)，这一笔“丶”要从上往下点(這一筆「丶」要從上往下點)。
examples.pinyin: Xiě Hànzì shí, zhè yī bǐ “zhǔ” yào cóng shàng wǎng xià diǎn.
examples.english: When writing Chinese characters, the stroke “丶” should be made from top to bottom.

examples.chinese: 雨字上面的两点是两个“丶”(雨字上面的兩點是兩個「丶」)。
examples.pinyin: Yǔ zì shàngmiàn de liǎng diǎn shì liǎng gè “zhǔ”.
examples.english: The two dots on the character 雨 are two “丶.”
